Title: "Harassment/Discrimination/Dishonesty - Welcome to Dell OKC Sales!"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for less than a year
Pros:
- High turnover so nobody cares if you leave. You shouldn't, either.
- Easy parking.
Cons:
Ooh! What an awful slice of dated corporate hell this place is! 

I came in as a University Hire to the sales department, only once there, they had no positions to fill (after lying to us that they did for months), so after hooking us with a signing bonus, they put us doing cold calls 40 hours a week, with no chance at bonuses/commission or advancement. The SWAT sales people not in the University program get the same treatment, only no benefits and $15/hr. One guy had been there 10 months at this rate as they kept stringing him along to becoming a permanent employee, with no end in sight. 

"Culture" is a word used solely to discriminate against those who are unsatisfactory -- be it due to race, sexual orientation, age, or general intelligence/business sense. Qualifications and experience mean nothing in favor of a low-cut blouse during the forced "mentoring" sessions with the piggish (nearly all) male managers. 

As for the bonus structure, Google "Dell fraud" and you'll find the company has violated tax laws and misreported it's numbers for TEN QUARTERS STRAIGHT! The "numbers" they pay you on and expect you to hit are complete and absolute fiction.

Avoid this place. The only people who succeed there are the ones who wouldn't anywhere else, which is why everyone you meet used to a be a "shopgirl" or "waiter" until working here. The (likely to be broken promise of) benefits got them hypnotized. This is not a good place to work for anyone with any actual earning potential. 

Since leaving, several hiring managers told me it was a good thing I left and it's actually a mark against you to have Dell on your resume in the tech world, as they have a reputation for not being able to fit in anywhere else. That fits, and since entering a position with decent management/transparency, I see what a truly negative and incompetently run experience this job truly was.

Title: "Good benefits but popularity contest culture"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: good benefits and I work at home.  Free t shirts/swag. I feel like the sales goals are attainable. I have learned a lot about IT and computers from this job.
Cons: I have never been promoted.  Pay is bad because of lack of promotions. There are very little women who work there and even less that get promoted. In order to get promoted they tell you to work on your "brand" but what that means is to cozy up to the right people and drink with them, etc. Everything is a popularity contest. 1 woman for every 10 men. In management - 1/20. Don't ever engage the help of HR because retaliation  happens all the time.  If you don't hit your number, they don't  care why. You will be out fast.

Title: "Be Careful"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for less than a year
Pros: fun perks - free food, vendors giving away stuff
Cons:
zero help for past employees - have not sent out W2s and it's february 18th have received 1095-c, but talking to anyone that is an actual person is impossible. 

about the job - i was hired as inside sales being told this is "inbound" sales, but when i got through training it was a bait and switch then being told i would be a "demand generation rep" in other words, i was cold calling. their only form of training is "dial more (not really but their training focused on selling and not their actual products) and you're constantly having to crawl over other employees who have already called the contacts you're given; i can not even begin to tell you how many times i've heard "someone else called me two days ago saying they were my point of contact, what is going on over there?!"  you do NOT have set accounts you handle. people are snakes and will steal your sales and leads. people do not tag the customer profiles like you should, or there are 17 different accounts for each individual and someone tags a random obscure account, and you're both working the same account. they say "scrub scrub scrub" accounts but how are you supposed to be thorough when there are MULTIPLE accounts, using different phone numbers all for the same people. they need to clean up their accounts system.  you are guilted out of taking PTO. while i was there, they offered over time but quickly rescinded that offer because people actually used it like they asked and expected beause nothing is better than SALES SALES SALES, so they offer over time only to then take it away beause people used it.

i was at the nashville anniversary gathering for Dell, and it was weird that we were asked to scream and cheer for Michael Dell like he was some kind of God. he came out to an imagine dragons song to show that he was cool with the young guns.

Title: "Excellent Company with the BEST people"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time
Pros: I've worked for several large companies and advertising agencies.  I believe, without a doubt, Dell is the best company to work for. The people I work for and with are outstanding, genuine and looking for ways of helping everyone succeed.  Not every day is roses, but to work for a company who is as focused in innovation and success as Dell is, allows everyone to be focused on the same goals. Most of Dell works remote 100% or at least 50%, this has made a huge impact on my work/life balance. I am able to work remotely at least 2-3 days a week. Excellent health and wellness benefits.
Cons: I've heard from others that it's too big of a company/people get lost in the largeness. I think you chose your own adventure.  If you want to be seen, make sure you are in front of leadership. Let your manager know that you are interested in other areas to grow in.

Title: "Culture Clash"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: Good pay, good benefits, smart people to work with, technology leader.
Cons: Dell Technologies the new name from resulting merger of Dell and EMC is a culture clash between two tech firms. Dell is a relaxed, telecommuting culture, take time off to recharge, closed for the Christmas holidays to spend time with family organization. EMC management wears as a badge of honor, how little vacation they take and expect you to do the same. If you are taking vacation you don't work hard. If you have to take vacation, take your phone and laptop with you. It's a "if your're not in the office to be seen you're not working" culture. EMC management scoffs at the idea a company would give employees time off for Christmas. No work life balance if you land in storage position. Look for a job on the server side of the business.

WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year
Pros:
-Flexibility 
-Work/Life Balance 
-Excellent benefits
-Top of market pay
Cons:
Dell on paper is a great company to work for. In real life, the culture is truly awful. Title: "The politics at the upper echelons are horrific!"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: The benefits continue to be quite worthwhile and I am glad to see that these have not been diluted.  There are many pockets where leading-edge technology is being pursued but one will end up at one by dumb luck rather than career planning.
Cons: Lack of information about what is going on, constant change to justify middle-management's effort to remain relevant in a changing market.  We are told to adjust to change yet nothing changes beyond additional administrative/bureaucratic process changes.  NO integration (only lip service) between Legacy Dell and Legacy EMC which makes career growth impossible.  You cannot jump from one legacy organization to the other.  As a result, there are a lot of yes-men in the organization.

Title: "Your experience very much depends on who your manager is. Highly political environment."

Pros: Mission is great and Michael is a wonderful CEO that is easy to get behind. Many smart people. Huge company - which can be good and bad.
Cons:
Highly political. While there are many wonderful people, there are also quite a few who behave badly and should be fired - but are connected and therefore get away with it. 

Can be a highly abusive place in certain pockets. There is also conversation that pay equity really isn’t close and yet diversity support is talked about as a strength. I watched a lot of very talented people be laid off simply because the leader didn’t like them or wanted to choose people they were friends with.

Title: "Dell Technologies Review - specific towards GCCS"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for less than a year
Pros: When applying for jobs, I applied to more than most (upward 150 applications towards different jobs). With this being said, I was blessed enough to have multiple job offers. So why Dell? Personally, Dell stood out. The position, the culture, the pay, the benefits, the work/life balance, the people... it felt too good to be true. From day one, Dell as a company and the people that it employees have been nothing but welcoming to me. They have included me in and out of the office. They have helped me with any questions that I have had and done so with an amazing attitude. They have given me resources throughout Dell to help me get involved in other areas. For example, my manager knew that I loved to party plan and told me about our group "Winning Culture" that plans all of Dell's events. I joined the group and have loved every second of it. They have encouraged me, challenged me, and are helping to shape me into the business woman that I'm becoming. The people here GENUINELY care about you. There is so much room to grow and change positions throughout the company. If you accept a sales job here and realize sales isn't for you, no problem. Dell is completely comfortable and actually encourages their employees to bounce around throughout the company to discover what they really love. There is so much opportunity for horizontal (moving from one position to another in a different area of the company) and vertical promotions (moving from one position to a higher position in the same area of the company). I have absolutely nothing but great things to say about this place. As a recent college graduate and this being my first job, I know that doesn't really qualify me to know much about the workforce, but as far as I know, there is no place like Dell. If you ever get the opportunity to work for this company, please do yourself a favor and accept the job.
Cons: I will let you know when I find them :)

Title: "Diverse and collaborative work environment"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Most people are collaborative and respectful. It's a diverse environment that encourages personal growth. Dell products are getting innovative and we have a complete product portfolio serving different size of customers from enterprise, SMB, to individual consumers. Work life balance and the flexibility to work remote is definitely a plus.
Cons: Sometimes getting information or data from other teams is not easy, hence dragging the work progress. It takes time to align with multiple stakeholders as well.

Title: "Political and Discriminations"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: Work Life Balance is great, people are good to work with.  Benefits are great.
Cons: Discriminates against minorities.  Been doing the job for over 4yrs and I have the same job title as my peers in all our regions, but they are one grade level above my current level.  Everyone starting to notice the discrimination, I usually dismiss their comments as jest when they bring it up because I don't prescribe to it or think about it that much, but when a person has done the job for X yrs and someone comes in that has no management skills, or done anything for the company that is significant, but still gets the promotion it makes a person think about it deeper especially when it happens on 5 different occasions.  What makes it worse, I have to clean up the promoted person's mess and it's clear the person has no business being a manager per peers and others within our Business Unit. I have been told by some peers that I should address this with HR, but I never wanted to be that GUY. By the way, this also happened one of my peers, guess what we had in common?!

Title: "Account Manager"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Great benefits and paid time off.  If you’re lucky to have a good account set excelling and career growth is possible!
Cons: Micro management.  They would rather replace you with a kid straight out of college then pay you the higher level you earned.  They provide cake quotas to newbies to prevent turnover while pushing tenured reps out the door with unattainable quotas.  Truth is I made $25k more when I started as 2 levels below what I am now because management buried me in quota as I moved up.  Upper management puts metrics on the reps that they have no clue of effect or backing to prove.  If a team is leading in sales revenue, but lowest on call numbers they catch all holy hell that they need to make calls because that executive NEEDS to prove the calls metric leads to the sales they preached it would.  If the forced metrics don’t meet what they preached it’s their job on the line so they threaten to make sure the numbers meet what they say works.  You never know how your quota is created or given a fair and accurate picture of how it was.  Management can load quota on different team members at their discretion.  Somehow you grow your accounts 20% after a 12% quota increase, but you miss your quota by 25% match doesn’t add up... Management blocks upward movement if they don’t have heads to fill your current role.  If you can get out of the sales seat and into a different role the company is amazing and job security increases 90%.  Sales reps are expendable and not appreciated.

Cons: Low pay, can be stressful during end of quarter/half, and management will string you along promising a job until eventually you have to choose a different department.

Title: "Transition from EMC to Dell was rough"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 8 years
Pros:
The transition from EMC to Dell after the merger was rough, but came with a few perks.

The Dell employee discount is generous and funded two computers and a television while I was employed there. 

Training is generous and, at least while I was there, vouchers for certification exams were fairly easy to get, but only for Dell/EMC certifications unless you had a manager willing to do the extra work for, say, an AWS voucher.

Work/Life balance largely depended on your client, not Dell. Dell by itself was pretty lenient about working from home as required, so long as you did not abuse the privilege.
Cons:
Being swallowed up by a much larger company squashed the career mobility of former EMC employees flat once the dust had settled. I wound up having to leave Dell to advance my career after two years of trying to move into a different position.

Compensation was therefore also flat with little to no chance of change.

Title: "Best employer in Austin"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: I never expected to work for the same employer for 10 years, but this is the type of company where you can build a career. All of my roles have been interesting and challenging (I can't speak for everyone, but the opportunities are here).  The Dell culture is welcoming and collaborative with many opportunities to mentor and to be mentored.  I think that the company has come a long way in terms of its approach to and investment in innovation that will pay off for years to come.  Although it's been said here many times, it's hard to beat a good work-life balance where you get to enjoy your vacation and have the opportunity to work remotely.
Cons: Despite many lateral opportunities, myself and others are challenged to find more senior roles after Director. In some cases, people feel like there is a preference for external candidates over internal. It's not unusual for people to "boomerang" out of Dell to get the promotion/bump and then come back versus waiting for something internal.

Title: "Great Overall Stability and Potential But You May Need Patience"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year
Pros:
- A stable job for a company that will be around for years to come
- Build YOUR business
- If you work hard to close and perform well, you will get paid well overall. 
- Pretty transparent about what you take home and where your commissions lie
- Lots of room for growth
- Plenty of benefits by being an employee
- Feeling of family
Cons:
- If you have a bad territory, you're screwed. 
- Can be difficult to advance without over-performing (which is not necessarily a bad thing but worth mentioning the expectations)
- High-octane environment where you need to wake up ready to bring it to really achieve. (again, not necessarily a bad thing, but it's worth noting)
- Can have an air of "who do you know" to get ahead although it's not pervasive and definitely not indicative of all locations and positions. 
- Some in Senior Management are only concerned about themselves and their appearance. 
- Upper management can be very disconnected because they are not driven by the same metrics as sales so they put out numbers or goals that do not always align at all.

Title: "Fantastic culture, with ample opportunity to grow and learn"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for less than a year
Pros:
Fantastic benefits, culture, and people. I've never interviewed at a company where people walk by and smile and say hello to a total stranger. I know that sounds like a small thing, but I think it goes to show you how happy people are that work here.

It's extremely flexible in terms of work/ life balance. Management understands that everyone is an adult and that you can manage your own schedule - there is automatic trust that if you made it through the interview process, you can handle your day-to-day tasks.

I love the 401k match, wellness options, and didn't opt into the health plan but have heard wonderful things.

I will say that post-merger, it seems like the dynamic is changing - I am a fairly new employee, but my initial impressions of Dell being a slower, seasoned, traditional company are quickly falling to the wayside. People move fast and nimble here. I really love that, coupled with the flexibility.
Cons: It's a large company, so if you're not used to rolling up your sleeves to get a question or issue addressed, this may not be the company for you. You have to sometimes dig and ask around a few times to get answers (which I enjoy, but not for everyone)

Title: "great company culture"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for less than a year
Pros:
The work environment is relax yet intense. We get to manage our own time and complete tasks at our pace.

We are not required to spend 8-9 hours a day sitting in the office; instead we are allowed to work at home as long as we got our job done. Even though sometimes we have to work extra hours, but being able to work at home definitely makes me feel better.

The managers are also very caring. They made sure your effort is recognized and spent time with you to help you understand the role you play in the team.

Finally, DELL puts a lot of effort to encourage the employees to participate in volunteering works.  This is not something I have seen in my previous job. I'm glad to have such opportunities to give back to the communities.
Cons: Many co-workers are located in different countries so it's difficult to arrange meetings

Title: "Is this a joke? There is no work-life balance and very few WFH jobs."
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: You can work from home 2 days a week, IF, you hit your quota. Good Benefits. Good Vacation.  Nice facility.
Cons: WFH is used as a threatening tactic. Management is chosen strictly through politics, most are unable to develop or help reps, most of the organization is unprofessional and disrespectful and no one is held to any standards. If you work hard and put in a lot of hours and hit your quota...management will leave you alone, but only those employees that are favorites benefit from any bonus, raises, and company trips.  Leadership is not held accountable for any of their actions such as behavior, ethics, morals, and equality. Bullying is tolerated. HR will not do anything to prevent poor behavior. If you want to be successful keep your nose down, work hard, stay quiet, be invisible, and suck up to your boss.

 --Top managers don't care about how changes affect the people down the chain.

Title: "a great place to find a retirement style career"

Cons:
- paperwork non-technical managers in highly technical engineering roles : You're on your own depending on team placement.

- work culture is partially locked in Waterfall, lots of old ideas from old-timers

Title: "A full, honest review for candidates considering this position from somebody who succeeded"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time
Pros:
- Money (Unlimited cap, lunches, spiffs)
- Environment (Contests, playful environment, coworkers can be friends)
-Big Company (Resources and career mobility)
-Education (Strong marketable skillset despite where your next move is)

I have been apart of three organizations, and I can say that Dell checks a lot of boxes. It is a great location, pay is very fair, and there is career growth so long as you hit your number and have good relationships with your peers and management. The skillset you develop will be very marketable (consultative selling, full-cycle closing, qualifying). This position will set you up for success, and you'll make a lot  of money and have a lot of fun along the way.
Cons:
-Detached leadership
-Unethical sales practices are celebrated
-Quotas are dependent on other people

The middle management is dangerously political with an unclear vision that directly impacts the morale of the floor. Since I've worked there, the culture has deteriorated. Quotas can be determined by favoritism. They are overhiring and the quality of hires have been declining. Management turns a blind eye to unethical work practices, and are in many instances rewarded because of the number they're able to hit with shady tactics.

Title: "Great total compensation  but  old school management style"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Benefits are great. Bonus structure is great, ranges from 8% to  15% to  25% (directors) to 40% for VPs and upwards... 401K is 6% match. Very good WFH solutions across the company, but that means early morning calls and late night calls to support global activities.  Very solid in terms of business vision.
Cons: The leadership is very old white men's club. Even though they keep touting women in leadership , in reality, majority leaders by far are men, white and old timers. Very less chance for younger folks to go up the ladder. They are extremely cheap in terms of spending on "fun" stuff. E.g. no free coffee, no good offsite, no free stuff for employees. They only pay  for customer engagement programs.

Cons:

- Very minor bumps in salary for staying in the same role, not withstanding performance. One will need to change roles to see any significant salary bumps.

Pros: Salary is usually 10% more than other corps pay for the same roles.

Title: "Glossy facade, but problems beneath the surface"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for less than a year
Pros:
Connected Workplace program gives workers flexibility in how they work - full and partial telecommuting, job sharing, etc

Compensation seems competitive

People stay with the company for a long time

Affordable medical benefits
Cons:
Because so many people in my function have been with Dell for years, there is a lot taken for granted.  Probably not unique to Dell; still, as a new hire, it's tough.  It's like pulling teeth to get information and guidance, and I'm just referring to within my own team!

Bit of bait and switch with my job - I was hired for my skills and experience in one area, and now I'm doing something quite different.  Had I known then what I know now, I likely would have removed myself from the staffing process.  I'm reasonably autonomous, but feel like I've been left to sink or swim in many ways. 

Conflict avoidant manager, so I'm having to figure out a lot on my own.  

I've had a number of payroll related issues, which leaves a terrible impression as a new hire.  I'm a salaried exempt employee, been around since January, and my pay still isn't quite right.  If I didn't need the benefits, I'd probably have resigned already. If I'm still around in 6-12 months, perhaps I'll feel differently.

Title: "Ok benefits, insane lawyers, mediocre tech comp"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: Some paid parental leave (for mothers and fathers); 401k with aftertax/roth contribution capability but poor fund selection.
Cons: Stingy pay in tech in Seattle.  Mediocre benefits (parental leave is only a few weeks); poor 401k fund choices.  Low level management is usually mediocre.  IT lives in the 90s and has poor security practices that interfere with work; nothing ever gets fixed.  Insanely verbose and invasive NDA / employee agreement / binding arbitration policy.  Solicits donations to corporate PAC from employees, which mostly funds conservative lobbying groups and campaigns.

I am beyond grateful to have this balance in my life to seamlessly flow between work and personal obligations. My management team is supportive and accessible in my career growth and development.
Cons: As with most companies the size of Dell, you are going to deal with quite a few meetings, emails and IM's!

Title: "Great company, great culture"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Great work life balance, employees are empowered for the most part to run their business the way they want provided they perform well & hit key metrics. Ability to work from home 2 days per week. Culture is FANTASTIC. Without a doubt one of the best jobs available in Oklahoma.
Cons: The account set you get is luck of the draw until you've been there awhile and proven yourself - there are hard working reps who get bad account sets and don't make as much money as they should and there are terrible reps who just luck into high performing accounts. Promotions sometimes boil down to who you know and how much you've networked more so than your work ethic & performance.

Title: "Good benefits"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Good benefits and decent compensation.
Cons: Can get stuck at a level from a comp perspective.

Title: "Great place to work, especially if raising a family"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros:
Multicultural, lots of opportunities to advance, good compensation.
If you get a good manager, they can really help you move up.
For the most part, the "Dell Culture" of empowering employees isn't just words on paper, most managers are seriously committed to helping you be your best if you show the drive.
Work/Life balance is amazing -- family leave policy is second-to-none.
Cons:
As with all large companies, the quality of your job will be highly dependent on your relationship with your manager.
Very low effort is spent on "skilling up" employees(unless you're moving into management), other than some very limited "online training" resources.

Cons: A lot of misalignment from management and the transformation teams. Attempting to make the company more lean and agile at the team level, while being mandated to in the style of traditional Waterfall.

Title: "Just another large corporation"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year

Cons: You get lost in a large company. It is highly unlikely that anything you do will be noticed. If it is noticed, it is rarely, if ever, a good thing.

Title: "Emcee was a great place to work. Things fell apart one fell took over"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: I have worked for EMC for over 20 years. The Egans were great to work for. They really cared about us and treated us great.
Cons: Place really went downhill when Dell took over. My job title was lowered from principle tech to senior tech which cut my money. Also benefits were torn apart by Dell. Blue cross blue shield of Illinois is the worst insurance I have had in over 20 years. They do not pay for the same things the EMC policies we had with had under EMC. It was a nightmare dealing with our current insurance plan. Moral all around the company is very low. You sitting there worrying about layoffs instead of doing your job. It is almost impossible to get a promotion unless you know someone.  Less quality people are always promoted overr quality people.

Title: "The job differed than what was presented initially"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for less than a year
Pros: Healthcare benefits, Garage Parking, working with other young people
Cons: I was under paid by a lot. Management did NOT know what to do with their newly hired college grads. Some members of management behaved very rude, and the other higher uppers seemed to just tolerate that sort of poor behavior. I was presented the job offer as a business systems analyst but my role was not as one. I was placed as a healthcare consultant. It was broad name that covers consulting, call center, accounting, project management, and a  few others. It was a weird time to get hired there during their a&m with NTTA Data. We were not made aware of this until the first day. I was given a hiring process packet to finish in two weeks as busy work and I completed it within days. After that, I sat around for months until I had my first project as a consultant. Shortly after, me and a few other newly hired college grads were laid off due to the a&m with NTT Data.  Majority of my former coworkers in my age group are no longer working with Dell/ NTT Data

Title: "Great start till a bitter departure"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Working here is a great entry point. You get in, learn a bunch, but don’t make it a lasting career. There are several good people to work with, and it can be fun.
Cons: Management does not seem to care about your interest or future. Very little movement/promotions. Some people tend to have egos. Extreme lack of real training toward certifications. In support, you are more reading from a script with management breathing down your neck to get back in the queue. The politics are bad, the tools are constantly changing which is a big annoyance. Be warned, if you go elsewhere competitively and provide a 2 week notice, they will walk you out and you will not get paid the two weeks.

Title: "Virtustream at Dell - Hard work and little appreciation"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Ability to work from home.
Cons: If you want a company that will work you to death, gives zero appreciation, small raises, and treat you terribly, this is the place for you. Virtustream is all over the place, they have way too much management and throw out senior director to anyone as long as they are completely incompetent and don't understand the product or operations at all. Public sector is an absolute train wreck and nightmare, upper management gives it no attention and the testing for the products that will run there are practically zero.  The business tries to focus its talent and time into things that customers aren't asking for, they don't listen to you, and operations is horrendously anemic. Another main issue is that the company basically encourages bad employees, you work like crazy and another employee does almost nothing - good work team, carry on. You work an entire weekend, up till 4 am on Saturday, good job, pat on the back. 80 hours of work in a week might occasionally get you a $100 "reward" for you efforts, enjoy your $2 an hour of overtime. The company basically treats its employees terribly, my family has had to have an intervention with me. A previous coworker I worked with had a similar experience and was encouraged to quit for her health from being so stressed and exhausted.

Title: "Great place to work and have a good work/life balance. Not the most challenging place though."
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: I worked in the server division as a firmware engineer. My management was great, hands-off, and very strongly supported their team members. The work/life balance was awesome in that management allowed you to have your own work style, hours, etc.. There were some very smart people here that are experts in their respective subject matters from whom you can learn a lot. There is a lot of career advancement possibilities here since there are many engineering titles. You definitely get recognized for your work if you make it visible and you will get rewarded for it. Personally, I was very happy with the team environment and the confidence of management to allow their engineers to make his/her own decisions.
Cons: There are lot of people with a cruising mentality here. The bar for entry isn't the highest so you won't be surrounded by really smart people. The work is interesting and challenging at first but being a server company, you're not really working on the most cutting edge things. I'd classify Dell as a reactive company vs. an innovations company. There's not a lot of money is invested in R&D. I feel like while engineering has a big presence, the focus is more on making money in sales and marketing. I just didn't feel challenged enough and wasn't fulfilled with the problems that I was solving. There's not as many perks as compared to the tier 1 companies.

Title: "Good if you are ok working autonomously then a ton of feedback"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies
Pros: Autonomy, collaboration, decent pay, work from home, latitude to make some decisions without a committee, creative outlet.
Cons: Whikle automony was expected, review cycles did not come, even though people reviewing the content had seen the progress - positioning, messaging, concepts - along the cycle. Many time there was no a lot of time to incorporate feedback and back flips ensued to get things done prior to launch in a GTM setting. While doing the work leading up to the launch of a product/service/software, executives were regularly updated on messages, positioning, content, deliverables, etc. HOWEVER, not all execs. attended the meetings, there were too many people with input power and a thousand requests for inclusion of other offerings on the products that were sure to get attention. So it was a tough balancing act. It wasn't until everything - especially a press release where all the aforementioned information was on two pages, was there a visceral reaction.  So then come the back flips - to hurry up an change any of the above where translations were already done and paid for...and would have to wait a quarter. Also, sometimes when you had the decision, there were internal fights over the decisions and groups, like development would hold the schedule hostage until one bent to their way of seeing things. HOURS WASTED. Finally, in all the cost cutting that went on, many groups would layoff or reassign people in an organization - let's say Online (responsible for the process and general design of webpages) - to show they were within their target cos-cutting. It looks great on paper, BUT the jobs that were vacated generally rolled up to the marketing manager who already had their hands full with photography, videos, content, brochures, aligning organizations, staying within brand guidelines, coordinating with the communications team, providing feedback on press relases, often time representing Dell at events or press briefings and getting all that coordinated by specific dates for translations, legal review and ultimately launch dates. So then there would be more added to the plate in addition to all the reviews with executives.

Health & wellness benefits are great.
Cons:
Company culture as a whole is not innovative, very set in it's old ways and incredibly risk-averse. It is difficult to do anything outside of the set path, and risk-taking is highly discouraged.

The onboarding process for new hires is fragmented and abysmal, people dont have laptops or passwords. Culture can change varying by team but it seems there is a general attitude of "not my problem".

Compensation and raises are capped at a very low percentage compared to other tech companies, even for high performers.

Title: "Culture Clash"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Tons of opportunity and upward mobility. The company has returned focus to providing quality products over the past year, support has greatly improved, and the company has done a great job innovating.
Cons:
Merger has chased away/downsized great leaders and individual contributors. As a result, the leadership quality has declined, and the manager to employee ratio out out of line. 

Dell has tried to commoditize the entire EMC portfolio, which has led to a counterproductive field sales clash, and led to a big shift away from an enabled sales force that understands the value of Dell EMC solutions and how they work together. Instead solutions are regarded as products, and likened to the same selling motion of a laptop. It's evident in the decline of field sales enablement and the removal of training opportunities. There are still Dell sales people incentivized to sell products that compete with Dell's own products.

Title: "Software Engineer"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: The salary and benefits are pretty good. There's also an actually decent focus on work/life balance. Aside from the occasional long hours before/during a release to production most people pretty much keep it to 40 hours/week. Most people also have flexibility to work from home at least part of the time.
Cons:
To put it nicely, on the whole I would say that Dell (or at least the engineering space) is a giant, inefficient, incredibly frustrating organizational mess. 

When the company went private several years ago a good chunk of the best engineering talent either quit or were laid off. Since then the direction from management seems to have been to outsource about 2/3 of all team members to India and to never get rid of under-performing employees. So over time as many of the great engineers are promoted up or leave the company out of frustration we've seen a steady degradation of overall quality on software teams.

There's also a frustrating amount of red tape to go through for every little thing. Want to deploy a bug fix to a test environment that will unblock several downstream teams for next week's release? Gotta wait until the end of the day when deployments are unlocked for 2 hours or else get a email sign-offs from 5 managers who don't know anything about your project, several of which may be asleep on the other side of the world.

Lastly, over the years I've seen management change hands and departments renamed so many times that I literally don't even pay attention anymore if it doesn't directly impact my team. And especially when upper management is changing around, there's a good chance somebody somewhere is getting laid off. Makes people nervous.

So to kind of sum up my pros and cons here, if you want a relatively stable job with good pay and benefits, decent work/life balance and flexible hours, and you don't mind dealing with a whole lot of frustrating nonsense tangential to your actual work then Dell might be a good fit. But if you're a real go-getter and want an exciting environment to work in then I'd suggest looking elsewhere.

Title: "Great pay and benefits, but too many changes from the executive team"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Awesome healthcare packages; wonderful 401K match; best college reimbursement I've seen; excellent employee work groups (supporting veterans, LGBT community, associates where English is a second language, and many more); They provide an on-site small gym, open 24/7; They offer an on-site cafeteria, but only during normal weekly business hours; They are heavily involved with the Utah corporate games; And they do contribute and encourage a lot of employee involvement in charity work (i.e. Utah food bank, habitat for humanity, STEM groups for kids, and volunteering at IT and STEM events around the Utah valley).
Cons:
Executive leadership at Dell is extremely frustrating. They make top down decisions about everything and leave managers constantly struggling to explain and keep up with changes (with zero employee or local management feedback).
The only issue with their healthcare package is for married couples, where the spouse has a full time job at another company. Dell EMC actually penalizes these employees, basically making it more affordable to just drop your spouses Dell EMC coverage.
One frustrating thing at Dell EMC is employee growth opportunities. They constantly have an extremely high turn over rate because people find it easier to leave and come back in order to get more money and/or promotions.
And the final thing that was most frustrating to me personally with Dell (not EMC), was the employee purchase program for Dell products. They provide an annual 17% discount, which is nice, but that 17% is based on the retail price of the products. They would really increase their own employee purchasing and using their own brand if they provide a better program where employees could purchase Dell equipment for around cost.

Title: "Technical Support Engineer III/Advisor at DellEMC"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: There are many training and development opportunities. Perks aren't impressive and seem to be gradually getting worse since Dell acquisition, but benefits are good and floor+regional level managers really do seem to have employee needs strongly in mind. Personally, I have found that initiative and hard work is rewarded and recognition is regular. There are financial rewards available for stand-out contributions as well. DellEMC has a great entry level program with good starting pay for new Technical Support Engineers. Emphasis on mentorship and coaching for new-ish (up to years in some departments) is one of the most positive aspects of building a career at Dell.
Cons: EMC seems to lag a good way behind the market in pay and it's not improved after Dell bought EMC => DellEMC now. I wouldn't call it bad, but workplace perks and efforts to raise employee morale/satisfaction isn't on the same level as most of the surrounding peer companies, including the large tech corporations in the area. Unfortunately, Dell (including DellEMC) does seem to be the type of big tech corporation that only compensates you fairly as you enter the company and doesn't do much to identify and hold on to superior employees. It's pretty standard that TSEs in these kinds of companies only stay for 2-3 years before they're being paid well under market value and move to another company to make any real progress (think 3%/year if you stay vs. staying 2-3 years then moving to another company with a 20% raise... even moving back a couple of years later for matching pay if you want).

Title: "TSR"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for less than a year
Pros: Benefits are cheap, all around the people you work with are nice, good PTO.
Cons:
The technical sales rep job is a literal nightmare. I came to Dell for the vast opportunities it boasted. Unfortunately...those's opportunities are seemingly at the very end of a long, dark tunnel. During the interview, I was very hesitant about the sales position. I had read pages of pros and cons regarding Dell and addressed them in the interview. I was told those reviewers were liars. Still, against my better judgement, accepted the position as I was told, "if you end up not liking the sales position there are thousands of other positions!" The 9 weeks of training were very informative, fun, and filled with the Dell koolaide but didn't shed a ton of light on the day to day of the job, which now I understand why. 

If you enjoy:
micromanagement
being told you'll lose your job if you don't make the sale
cold calling people begging for their business 
Being lied to about your commissions
Weekly change of your quota and metrics

then this job is perfect for you. I find myself either bored to tears or stressed to tears with no in-between. The turnover here is incredibly high. I've already started prospecting for another job. Why you ask since there are so many opportunities? HA well, you are forced to stay in your position for 18 months and it's virtually impossible to move out of the sales rolls as all these ridiculous metrics they put on you are impossible to obtain. AWESOME. Also beware....when you do decide to look for another job, if you leave Dell within 2 years you have to pay them back your supposed 3 month guarantee of $5,000 (another thing they boast in the onboarding that doesn't exist) 

This place is sketchy, corrupt, and a living anxiety attack. 

Seriously - do your research. really think about it before you sign the papers. there are so many better opportunities out there.

Title: "The most Toxic company in the valley"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year
Pros: Nothing I can think of.
Cons:
Where to start?

Politics – Totally passive aggressive.  Everyone is pretending to be your friend all the while they are trying to stab you in the back to get ahead.  Head of departments avoid confrontation at all costs.  How do you rise to a VP or SVP without dealing with confrontation? Lying is expected and encouraged here.  This gets funny because they forget which lie they tell to who and routinely get caught and laugh it off.  They won’t outright fire someone, scared to so they pick at people until they’ve had enough and quit.  

Collective IQ – This is the dumbest company I’ve ever worked for, they give new meaning to the Peter Principle.  Now don’t get me wrong, there are smart people here but on a whole, the smart people can’t raise the collective IQ.  Everyone is waiting for their green card to exit this company.

Petty – Had to go over to see it myself.  They have management in another building that counts disposable cups and complains that too many are being used.  They have posted signs on the coffee machine that only people that work in his group or visitors can have drinks or snacks.

Benefits – Worst benefits in the valley, full stop, real third world stuff.  They had a “Tell Dell” survey last year and benefits came out as something major for the company.  In the end the only change they made was reducing the company matching 401K and benefits stayed the same.  When I started, I had to bring in proof that my kids were indeed mine.  People having to pay out of pocket for routine test that at every other company I’ve work at were covered, things like blood tests, x-rays etc. are not covered.  Don’t get me started on their “health screening and wellness”, employees signed their health history away for ~$600 or two months out of paycheck contribution, now they have people’s health history, god knows what they’re planning to do with it.   BTW, if you’re a fan of drug testing, then Dell has something waiting for you.

IT – Absolutely nothing works, their systems, their laptops and/or desktops.  They force an operating system that resembles Windows and everything is locked down, access to outside internet resources, applications, everything, still didn’t stop wide spread virus problems from hitting the company.  Their hardware is the worst, someone in another builds laptop almost started on fire in his bag on the way home.  Machines routinely reboot for no reason and ports are disabled.

They have an application for every function.  There are literally hundreds of applications that you have to use for PTO, Benefits etc. and most only work through IE6.  You have to get permission to have admin rights on your machine but still can’t do anything.  They made a change to accessing email, forcing everyone to windows and outlook, this left the Linux engineering community out in the cold.  All meetings run through Skype which barely works.  It normally takes 5 – 10 minutes to get a meeting started because of Skype issues.

Travel – There isn’t a published process on travel other than to be cheap (except if you’re an executive). I know someone that had a medical issue that had to travel and after a doctor’s excuse and weeks of process hurtles, they got a dispensation to travel in business internationality.  This was scrutinized by management and called into question every time they were required to travel.  Reports on “exceptions” are reviewed by the division heads quarterly and you don’t want to be on that report.

Tell Dell – They tell you that the internal survey is anonymous, yet you have to put in your userid.  You give them honest feedback and they know where it came from.

HR here for their own good.  The have HR reps for every function and they are all over the country.  The routinely skip the people they are working for, manufacture problems and go to the division heads so they can look good.  One of the heads of HR would not meet with employees until they submitted questions in writing.  When they didn’t get enough, the person cancelled meeting with employees because he was afraid of what they might ask him. 

Have and Have nots:  Sr directors and above get perks, travel in business, paid phones, special laptops and other perks setting up a class system in the company.  

And just in case, micro management is also king here, to get an expense report or anything completed it needs to involve at least 4 – 5 layers of management reminiscent of a 1950’s manufacturing culture. 

Bottomline here – I could go on but let’s leave it at, this is the most toxic company I’ve ever seen in the valley.

Pros: It is employment, kinda sorta.
Cons:
The stories you’ve heard are true, it’s a modern day sweatshop. They are hopelessly understaffed, and intentionally so, because it saves them money. They will heap a simply impossible amount of work upon you. You will find yourself spending your entire workday wandering from pointless meeting to pointless meeting. During each conference, you will have several hours of work assigned to you, with no time to actually perform the assigned tasks. At the end of the day, management will simply tell you to “get it done for tomorrow”. The implication being that you’re supposed to get out of work, and then go back to work - from home during the evening. I regularly get email from my coworkers around 3:00 AM because they’re still up at that hour doing the work that they were assigned during the day. They come in to work exhausted the next morning, looking like death warmed over, because they were up working all night and got no sleep. It is common for management to dump 20+ hours of work onto your lap at 4:00 PM on Friday afternoon and order you to have it completed for Monday morning - so much for your weekend. Needless to say, there will be no time for vacations. Just work, work, and more work. What kind of a life is this?

I’ve seen young kids in their early 20’s need to be on medication just so they can cope with their jobs. It will eventually catch up to you and make you sick. When that happens, you become a liability. It would expose the company to further liability if they were to terminate you because they made you sick, so instead they will try to torture you into quitting on your own. They will double down when you are on the verge of collapsing and heap even more work upon you. They will write falsely negative performance reviews and otherwise make you so miserable that you just can’t stand it anymore. If you refuse to quit, you will simply be eliminated in their next round of contrived layoffs, which are pretty much constantly ongoing. Then they will bring in a fresh piece of meat to replace you and work them to death next. I have never seen such an incredible rate of turnover. They should install a revolving door on the front of the building, oh wait, they did! Seriously, the rate of sickness and heart attacks is shocking, several people have even died.

It all boils down to one word: EXPLOITATION. Maximum exploitation of everything and everyone that they come into contact with. I have never seen such a Marxist commodification of human beings. During my orientation, the HR rep actually said “We are the Borg. You will be assimilated. Resistance is futile.” (look up the science fiction reference if you’re not familiar with Star Trek). They went on to tell us that “EMC stands for ‘Eventually Marriage Counseling’ because of all the long hours that we are going to make you work”. They might as well say “welcome to the company, we’re going to ruin your marriage”. Honestly, they actually said these things to us during our orientation!

They expect you to put the company before all else in your life. It is supposed to come before your home, your family, your relationships, your happiness and even your health. This loyalty and dedication will not be returned though, in fact, they will screw you in a heartbeat if it saves them a nickel. Virtue is a vice at this place and they are an inhuman calculating machine that operates completely without a conscience. Their employees mean absolutely nothing to them and “corporate ethics” truly is a contradiction in terms here. There is a striking lack of policy regarding the treatment of workers, and a striking lack of enforcement for what little policy there is. They will berate you, humiliate you, belittle you, insult you and torture you. Coercion is basically the only form of motivation that they know. If your manager wants to put a gun to your head in order to extract an additional 3% output, well that’s just fine with the executives – in fact, it’s commendable. They basically let managers do whatever they want. And you know what they say about absolute power…

HR is complicit in the corruption. When management wants to screw you, it is HR’s function to basically “grease the skids” and see that it is done in such a way that does not expose the company to liability. They are experts in re-writing history, deception, underhanded behavior, dishonesty and getting around the law. It's like something out of the dark ages. You are not going to get a chance to tell your side of the story, you will simply be ambushed on your way into work on some random day. It’s every dirty trick in the book, and several more that they have invented on their own. Every argument is one-sided and they’ve basically discovered that dictatorship is a very efficient form of government.

As a condition of being hired, you are forced to sign the most onerous and draconian document that I have ever seen. It includes such conditions as allowing the company to access your private email accounts and waiving your right to sue. That’s right, you must give up your 7th Amendment rights and agree to resolve any disputes through their arbitration process. I can just imagine what kind of justice you will get from the company court. Just why do you think they’re doing this?

Every relationship is adversarial, rather than cooperative. Management against workers, groups against other groups, workers against each other. Once management realizes that you don’t trust them anymore, they will approach you through someone that you do trust (usually a colleague) and screw you through them. You will eventually arrive at the accurate conclusion that you can’t trust anyone. This culture is completely toxic, but they ridiculously try to sell it as “excellence”.

Incompetent people are constantly promoted to senior level positions, while exceptional workers are trapped in menial jobs. It gets to the point where titles don’t mean anything at all. They would much rather hire cheap workers than talented ones. They especially prefer foreigners or young kids who can be tricked into performing multiple people’s jobs and working 80 hours per week for low pay. Key contributors are regularly eliminated because management basically figures that they have already extracted most of what they’re going to get out of them. Politics is king and the old boy network truly runs the place. Working here is like being trapped in a spider’s web: the more you try to struggle, the more entangled you'll become, and it will eventually kill you. Ultimately, it’s just best to stay away from this place.

Title: "Avoid this place at all costs!"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Adequate pay, but absolutely not worth it.
Cons:
They are literally working people to the point of sickness and death. Had to attend my coworker's funeral after he died of a heart attack brought on by work related stress at the young age of 38. He left a wife and children behind. Know of several others that died under similar circumstances here. The ambulance carries people out of this meat grinder on a regular basis. Almost funny when the rescue truck parks directly under their "Great Place To Work" banner (it should read: "Arbeit Macht Frei").

Their regular and unjustified layoffs are used as purges to eliminate those who can't be legally terminated. Once they make you sick, they see you as a liability to them and you will be ambushed at the next layoff, which is never very far away.

In a blatant effort to remove anonymity from their employee satisfaction survey, management actually exported a copy of the survey onto an external website and forced us all to take it there, before submitting the real one - just so they knew exactly who said what about them. Imagine this: people are literally dropping dead around you and you're supposed to say what a wonderful job management is doing, or you will be laid off.

Never have gotten a raise and have never even been paid my full salary in all the years I've been here. You will be forced to carry the workload of 6 or 8 different positions combined into one job. Everyone here is miserable and management has got "railroading" innocent people down to a science. Backstabbing, incompetence, corruption and politics are all rampant. The best thing you can do at this place is to leave. Haven't seen people treated this way outside of a concentration camp!

Title: "Horrible place for immigrants and lacks teeth in technology"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Absolutely none, Nill, how can I fill 5 good words!!!
Cons:
Age old technology.

Senior engineers take decisions on how APIs should look and junior engineers code it out. This model is so flawed that nobody takes complete responsibility for a component. Those who design APIs keep reworking because they lack the insights into implementation details and those who fill in the APIs have little idea of how it applies across components.

Legal team is a big let down and yet the company supports it with max trust. They have messed up so many of the employees through faulty applications, untimely filings, illogical suggestions, and so on. They are totally incompetent and they walk unchecked, unaccountable for any glorious blunders that they do. I have personally seen more than a dozen of my H1B colleagues leave this organization just for immigration purposes. More are in line!! My advice: If you are on H1B, stay away from this place.

Being in bay-area and not have RSUs is like the biggest joke. Once Dell took over EMC, all RSUs were taken away and most of us are left with 50% of TC. Only a small fraction of employees are getting long-term incentives and that's been thrown like biscuits to dogs in the range of 5K-10K for 4 years vesting.

Even people at VP level discuss on issues as small as why this API is looking this way and managers hold meetings all day to go through gory details of several components without having a clue of what they do and how they perform. Managers are zero quipped with technical ability and yet they work day and night on technical decisions.

By the way, this cry is all about DataDomain.

All receipts and expense reports were submitted. However, a glitch required manual linking of expenses between systems. After opening a ticket with internal helpdesk and leaving the company, the ticket was closed with no actual actions on the company part and I am left with a large bill from company approved expenses and travel from projects.

Although I was lucky enough to find someone experienced with mentoring young writers, it was an upward battle for support to grow in a direction indirectly related to my day to day job.

Title: "Executive Assistant"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: • Successful at luring new young employees in thinking they’re going to get the “EMC” experience. False! That no longer exists; which is fine if the business model improved after M&A, but it has declined significantly.
Cons:
• M&A between Dell & EMC still in the process after almost 2 years, systems still not synced making it extremely difficult to perform ones job at a high level.
• Disconnect between upper management and employees. Communication almost non-existent. 
• IT support horrible! Being told something simple can’t be done, then having to “YouTube” how to DIY.
• No longer local HR on-site; only HR available is in Dell HQ [Austin, TX], or online chat...who then directs you to speak to local HR, which is not there [?]
• False advertisement of “enjoyable engaged culture”...ice cream socials, LIFT committees, DO NOT equate to people being heard, it’s just a smoke screen.

* not a disgruntled employee, just anonymously stating the truth! *

Title: "The Dell CULTure is infecting a great thing"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros:
Very smart people to work with
Encourages work-from-home
For those who travel, a decently liberal travel policy
Decent work/life balance
Cons:
Dell CULTure is infecting the EMC culture. Given that EMC itself had a strange culture, it was still a company people loved, both employees and, clearly, enterprise customers. With the Dell merger it is all going in a terribly wrong direction because the Dell CULTure is truly an infection that'll take a gold standard enterprise company and turn it into the "race-to-the-bottom" box slinger, like Dell has always been.

Also, it is very clear the debt is taking a toll on the company, so it creates an uneasy atmosphere.

WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: You can change jobs every 18 months. They have cafeterias in every building, you can order food to your desk, and have fresh robot-made coffee!
Cons: Organization and political complexity. Constant changes! Many of the leaders at VP or higher level only care about themselves at the expense of doing what is right for Dell. Many defy the question “if you were Michael Dell, would you make that decision”. Title: "Dell is a Great Place to Work"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for less than a year
Pros: Dell has a great culture of networking, you are able to reach out to anyone and set up time to chat. Dell is all about results, so they are flexible when it comes to working from home and work/life balance. As long as you deliver what you need to and perform well they are happy. They strive to be #1 in every business and shows by the investments they make and the money they are willing to spend to be the best. It's great working for a company that strives for that.
Cons: The onboarding wasn't as well developed for non-University hires and I didn't feel I received the best overview of Dell upon arrival. But, over time I have been able to go to trainings and gain that knowledge.

Title: "Good People But Terrible Management"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year
Pros: The people you work with are seriously some of the best out there. Everybody was willing to teach when it came to a new person joining the team.

Title: "Enterprise Support Engineer II"

Title: "Command Center Specialist"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year
Pros: The name brand and location
Cons: DELL EMC (Draper): Heavily micromanaged and feels more like a sweatshop than a modern company. The only employees who can benefit are the managers who never change because they want to keep their positions. They only hire managers from outside the company so never dream of progressing while working there. Expect to work as a contractor for at least 2 years before they convert you to full time. The pay is below industry standard for the jobs they have. $16/hour to start and they may raise you up to $20 maximum after several years. You can find much better jobs in the valley that pay more than $20 and they provide you with benefits and you are full time from the get go. They use very old software technolgies and provide you with at least 6 tools to use instead of 1 centralized ERP that makes your life easier. They hold you responsible for any tiney maual mistake you do and act like jerks. Team members think they're managers and there is lots of conflict. You only get 2 15 minute breaks and you need to tell all your co workers when you go to the bathroom. You want my advise skip anything that says Dell EMC.

WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year
Pros: After two years I can say that joining Dell has been a great experience. I have an enormous amount of flexibility when it comes to doing my job. The compensation is fair and on par if not better than competitors and peers. I am able to balance my personal and professional life. There are a lot of rewards and benefits to be had if you know where to look.
Cons: You will need to advocate for yourself and learn to maximize the benefits and rewards that are available to you. There is not a lot of hand holding and finding mentors might be a concern for some. Onboarding is more of a sink or swim experience. Being proactive and open to learning will be a must in order to succeed. If you struggle with those things, you might face some challenges and frustrations.

Title: "Keep moving....or you will sink"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros:
-It was an honor to work for Michael Dell.
-Great vision and strategy from executive management.
-Decent Benefits and great 401K
-Good money when you over achieve....but you will be capped. 
-Generally good corp culture....even though there are tons of slackers.
Cons:
-Territories shrink, customers are taken away, quota keeps going up. 
-Standard OTE is low for industry. When you over achieve, they try to get you closer to OTE.
-Capped commissions. 
-Mid level management lacks any courage. Manage by spreadsheets and are not true leaders. 
-Negotiate the best salary you can. You will not get a raise and promotions are rare. 
-Need to keep reinventing yourself and move to different positions. You can perform yourself out of a job. 
-Constant customer satisfaction issues due to product quality and solutions engineering. 
-30%+ of your time will be spent on administrative tasks and meetings. Constant fire drills.
-Getting people to do their job is like pulling teeth. Lots of corp slackers. 
-Very poor work/life balance. 
-Not bleeding edge technology. Dell always seems a bit behind.

Title: "Good place to work."
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
Impressive gamut of technologies at DELLEMC that are the leaders in their respective fields [for the most part]. 

Very competitive pay, opportunities for advancement. Flexible schedule and decent opportunities for advancement.

A lot of training available and flexibility to choose how you spend many days. I liked to take 4 hours once a week for some dedicated time for developing a knew skill. 

Good benefits, tuition reimbursement, etc…
Cons:
Company culture in Utah seemed exclusive from my perspective, I found it difficult to get along with colleagues in a casual setting. 

Highly competitive with no clear indicators for success. Likely related to the High attrition in management.

Nearly two years since the acquisition by Dell and there are still several redundancies that duplicate workload related to the knowledge base, Code Base, CRM, HR, AR/AP. 

Inequality among employees with regards to responsibility, and almost zero accountability among support staff.

Title: "Good Products and Challenging Job"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
Good Pay
Good Products
Good Support
Overall good working environment with the tools to be successful
Cons:
They have conditioned the customers to buy at the end of the month or the end of the quarter to get the great deals. Executives come to town and give away deep discounts to close deals that otherwise may close in near term.

If the customer doesn't have the ability to buy at the end of the month / quarter for any number of reasons the pressure tactics can create a deal breaker.

Reps will dump accounts that they did a "one and done"  see you in 3 yrs end of quarter deals leaving the quota and the account clean up / possible broken promises for the new guy.

The sales jobs are good for 2.5-4 years. The guys that last longer have a few good established accounts that continue to produce.

Title: "Run Away"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Salary and benefits were decent.
Cons: Lot of favoritism.  Doesn't matter if you are top performer or on a  long term project you will be laid off. The more you butter up your manager the better probability you can survive. If you are on visa stay far away from this company. They laid off mostly everyone  who were on visa on residency and asked them to move to the partner with same salary but meager benefits, no 401k and no expenses. They will try to manipulate you  and won't pay any severance and pressure you to accept partner position because you are on a visa .

Title: "Frustrating experience as Software Engineer on the "transformation team""
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year
Pros: Good pay for the effort of work. Very laid back work place. I probably work 25 hours a week and spend the rest of the week learning.
Cons:
As a software company Dell is unable to innovate because IT department heads are always fighting each other. In the time I've been here I've seen new ideas and innovation squashed by micro managers and inter-departmental disputes. Managers tend to protect their friends and have normalized a very aggressive, non-collaborative behavior.

There is an enormous drive to make the boss happy so work is constantly being re-prioritized to meet the whims of "leadership"

Overall pathological organizational culture. Almost no one can offer or take constructive feedback because any honesty would spoil their reputation among their peers. Interpersonal issues that could be avoided by a little honesty and feedback often degrade into overtly heated arguments or passive aggressive scheming. I've personally witnessed at least 3 of my co-workers throw each other under the bus to "get ahead."

Title: "Front Line Support is brutal"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Foot in the door; You learn a lot.
Cons:
Very Political. Little room for movement. Limited training and certifications.
Minnesota location compiled of actual knowledgable technicians are being depleted and positions are being moved to OKC and Round Rock with staff who know absolutely nothing about the product, so support will be even worse. Dell takes a good name like Compellent and destroys the product by ruining the support. As the transition occurred, it became scripted like a typical call center. There is a lack of movement here. Dell Management has no idea what support is actually like and they change structure based on their SLA stats.
Delta is the worst application. I will never recommend a Dell product ever after working for this company.

Title: "Good until Dell acquisition"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Went through a phase where it stepped out of its legacy process and incubated or acquired some data storage software for modern environments. Lot of success during that phase as well as some innovation. Was able to attract and retain some top notch engineers during this phase. If you are good, you got to work on some interesting distributed systems problems. Unfortunately this phase ended with Dell merger.
Cons: After Dell, the team I was on, was essentially wrecked. Hiring freeze and no attempt to retain best talent meant all good engineers left.  Tried to make up by aggressive hiring  in cheaper countries but those teams couldn't cope and project quality took a deep dive. No development of new features - all the time spend on trouble shooting. Obsessed with sales but lost customer goodwill due to declining product quality.

Depending on your role there are remote work options. Other great benefits around employee wellness and discounts. The Dell employee purchase program can really save you some money.
Cons: Large company that goes through a lot of changes. You will get shuffled around a lot to new groups and managers. I am on my 6th director in 5 1/2 years. Career growth can be limited depending on the group you are in and you may have to seek out an internal move to be able to move up.

Title: "Dell at a high level"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time
Pros: Depending on the team that you're in, there can be a lot of flexibility in your work schedule which is very nice. The company is also investing in updating its facilities to create a more modern work environment.
Cons: There is a fairly conservative and risk-averse culture throughout the company, and it does not provide many of the daily office perks that many have come to associate with tech companies such as free lunches, beverages, etc. It also feels like the company takes work flexibility a bit far in terms of feeling like it would rather it's employees not come into the office, which reduces the ability for employees to collaborate spontaneously or build their network.

Title: "Was  a great place to work...once"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time
Pros: Paid Christmas shutdown week, work from home options, great people, on-site gym and cafeteria
Cons: The fear of layoffs is a constant at Dell EMC now. What used to be a once-a-year thing, now is a year-round constant process. Since Dell acquired EMC, there's been a lot of changes. A lot more documenting and reporting. Benefits seem to get worse and worse by the year (we used to have 6+ options for health plans, now we have 2 - HSA and a not-so-great PPO), a working spouse penalty (not sure it's even legal). A lot was promised, but all we see is tons of layoffs and benefit cuts.

Title: "Too Corporate"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for less than a year
Pros: There are a lot of good folks at the company. The pay is decent and benefits are still good compared to the rest of the industry.  You can find work life balance , very flexible about working from home , time off. At this point probably a really good place to start a career in the industry but don't stay to long..
Cons: The social culture of Dell is very cookie cutter corporate america. Some of that had permeated into EMC but Dell seems to impose a lot more of it along with hours of superfluous online  training -  I don't go to work to be socially engineered - I go there to make money. I expect a certain amount of required training on  corporate policies but its a bit heavy.  More importantly it is obvious innovation is a thing of the past at this company. They keep up  with the rest of the industry and do a great job at maintaining what will become the legacy of the industry. In other words, the downward spiral that often happens to excessively large companies is starting. I suspect they are headed down the path of many of the companies that were once great.

Title: "Started off well under EMC, but the wheels fell off after the Dell acquisition/merger."
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Company does/did allow employees to chase knowledge, learning and certifications. It’s a huge company, and is a leader because of its size.
Cons: Everything is being moved offshore. There is no loyalty from the company, especially since the Dell acquisition. There are always work force reductions going on now, and there is very little strategy around why. Dell finance now controls everything, and will make poor decisions that can flip a project from profitable to negative overnight, with no impact on them but all the impact passed on to delivery teams. Messaging from leadership is spotty and tries to obscure the truth. Everything that was promised during the merger has been put to the wayside, and benefits have slowly gotten worse. Cost cutting is everything, even when it negatively impacts employees and clients.
