Title: "Executives Change Direction Like The Hill Country Winds"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Once you're  Dell-badged, there really are great medical, dental, and vision benefits, plus a corporate matched 401k and corporate matched funds for qualifying charitable contributions, which you can have deducted from your paycheck. The time off after 5 years with the company in the US is 4 paid weeks of vacation plus 2 weeks of personal/sick time off as well. Until recently, the work/life balance score would have rated as a pro, too, since Dell was finally catching up on letting its employees work remotely so as not to be tethered to a cubicle in a hot Central Texas office for a job that can be done over Skype and email from anywhere. Alas. . .
Cons:
It seems that each year the executive leadership in charge of IT either abdicate and flee or they get pitched some new & improved methodology or business model that requires a major upheaval of the existing organizations and interrupts the in-flight projects being worked under last year's buzzworthy methodology. 
Next year, some enterprising young consultant will probably show them a time- and money-saving new method involving three-toed sloths embedded in the on-site teams, and the execs will fly in dozens of sloths to try and make that model work. When they do, I hope they post lots of videos, because sloths are ridiculously adorable, even from a corporate hell hole that's lost all empathy for its employees.

Title: "Endless possibilities!"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for less than a year
Pros: They are very open minded to new creative ideas and ways to work, even though it’s a big company with many guidelines. They truly work with diversity and are not afraid of hiring people with “different” backgrounds. The best thing is also the flexibility!! I have the possibility to work from wherever I want in the world, home or in the office. There are also tons of groups you can join within the company if you wish (women at dell, branding, planet, etc). I truly recommend Dell EMC!
Cons:
Big company- a lot of guidelines and processes but this is usually common no matter what big global company you work for.

In my team (across emea) we don’t have a big travel budget so we don’t meet often and when we do it’s budget style. Depends on what you like and are used to. 

Its heavy coming to such a big company if you are not used to it, the onboarding could have been better.

Title: "CPSD/Ready Solutions needs to become extinct."
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Great processes, when they are actually followed properly. Great core businesses  (server, storage, client, networking and services) but the solutions division is a  flop and has been since it was originaly created.  Anyone remember "AIM or BVD?"
Cons:
There is no effort to obtain and infuse customer insights into product design or plan phase exit prior to bringing a "solution" to market or creating a soon to fail GTM plan.

There is a severe lack of cohesive research, engineering beyond validation, customer inspired design and messaging, outbound marketing, channel enablement, meaningful claims testing or product differentiation of your solutions.

Dell cannot even demonstrate how they use their own solutions internally to resolve complex problems.

Title: "Solution Architect"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year
Pros: Work/Life balance is truly considered important and held in high regard. Diversity of people and skill sets, management’s approach to employee growth and maintaining a strong positive company culture. Upper levels really listen. Customer centric approach to solutions and all-around satisfaction.
Cons: 3 year roadmap does not exist. With double digit growth year over year sometimes direction can get cloudy. There is always high level goals, but the devil is in the detail.

Title: "Great organization"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years

Title: "Working at Dell is like Rearranging Furniture on the Titanic"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Work from home for inside reps, decent benefits, etc.
Cons:
Company culture has really fallen downhill over the last decade.  Dell does a great job marketing outward but seems to invest very little in people, tools to do the job, etc.  Dell is great at purchasing great companies, but the lack of integration leaves a lot to be desired (this dates back to acquisitions from many years ago ie Kace, Boomi, Credent).  Outside of package selling and leveraging the PC business in cheap base growth strategies, the technology and sales motions are a huge question mark.  

Leadership...I dont know where to even start.  Somewhere between when I started in 2005 and now, the culture and leadership shifted from being one of mentorship and learning to titles and good ole boy clubs.  Dell preaches meritocracy, but it's not implemented in any way, shape or form.  Even voicing a concern - ie not getting paid for something you sold - was extremely discouraged.  Depending on a paycheck within a sales job and feeling like you were getting rewarded for your efforts and earnings was a complete joke.  Across multiple roles, leaders, departments, etc., I finally realized that the CULTURE had completely changed into a toxic environment that required "dealing with ambiguity" to be a core competency simply because no one seems to know what they're doing.  Even worse, no one cares.

Dell doesnt do in role promotions or raises - you almost always have to find another job (and hope that there's no hiring freeze on movement) to get a promotion.  If you hear that there is a strategic overlay that is a "startup inside of Dell" - RUN.  RUN FAST.  I was part of 4 different "strategic overlay" roles, many of which were acquisitions, that shut down within 6-9 months of forming the division.  Trying to interview outside of this crazy environment to leave the company was a constant justification of why I had moved around through so many roles so often -- 1) to make money and 2) because Dell kept shutting down divisions they'd just started.  I doubled pay by leaving, doing the exact same role for a different company.  And luckily, people are really nice where I'm at now.

Title: "Tough place to work"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: When I started in 2011, salaries were competitive and it was still run like a typical company - some bureaucracy, reorgs that seemed to do nothing, but staffed well enough to accomplish most of our goals if we worked hard.
Cons: Cost savings killed it as a place to work.  They brought in workers from offshore to replace US staff,, understaffed our area, provided just enough support to  not to lose contract with client - but nowhere near enough to keep client happy.   Reorganized so usual departments - like HR - became managed services and were pretty much unavailable. I had an employee who needed to be on short term disability and it took me several workdays worth of calls/emails/hanging out on hold to get information on how she could apply for it.   Staffing became a nightmare because they insisted we go through specific vendors that provided low-quality resumes via unworkable web portals.  Overall an unbelievably miserable experience.

Title: "Insurance sucks"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: the people I work with.
Cons: I have been out of work for almost one year do to having cancer.  The short term disability through Cigna is almost nonexistent.  Cigna will put you through what ever they can do to give you wrong information.  Then when long term happens you will be required to pay your benefits from you Social Security check of $1700 per month.  The Dell EMC will not send the billing address or the cost so you can pay the benefits.   They will tell you if you do not get the payment in by the first of the month, you have a grace period.  However, during the grace period they will not pay any of the claims that come in.  It is costing me 2700 dollars a day.  Selling my house to pay bill.

Salary plans are a step behind:
 - Engineering salaries are partly an "MBO" which is actually "salary at risk", meaning it won't be paid if things beyond your control don't happen, such as sales goals.
 - Raises are subject to downward adjustment for reasons other than personal performance; e.g. promotions for others, the performance of the division.
 - The merger with Dell is fomenting sub-standard raises as Michael Dell has noticed EMC Massachusetts pay scales are higher than Dell Texas-based payscales.

Title: "Over a decade at Dell Services / Consulting / Professional Services"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
Overall Dell is a meritocracy and if you can produce you will be rewarded.  The people are fair, good and generally work hard.  Other pros include:
* Encouraged to do the right thing for the customer
* Everything is above board and straightforward including sales
* Customers tend to follow the straightforward honest work of Dell itself
* Teams tend to exist for long periods of time without a lot of churn meaning that the teams are strong.  In other words your immediate teammates will be there and work with you. 
* Dell is very serious about the Tell Dell annual survey which is an opportunity for the rank and file to give feedback to all levels of the organization in an anonymous fashion.  I've seen this correct problems with 'challenging managers' and bad teams. Dell is focused on keeping it's people.
Cons:
There are still merger activities going on between Dell and EMC creating a little bit of instability between the different units.  In general this is smooth, but sometimes it creates conflicts between different units. 
Another con is career development.  In the early days it was pretty easy, as Dell grew promotion generally comes via lateral transitions to opposite teams.  This can be considered a pro as well in that once in a role, it tends to be pretty stable without a lot of immediate team churn.

-Cube farm environment.

Title: "Health Plan Costs Increase Astronomically for 2018 - over 300%"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time
Pros: Great team environment with verbal recognition
Cons: New Benefit package for 2018 came out, and I wondered why the web ex over emphasized how great it was - now we know - health benefits (even for an HSA plan!) went up 300%.  To try and compare apples to apples, you have to call 8 different numbers - 1 for next years enrollment, 1 for this years enrollment and costs to date, 1 for FSA for this year, 1 for FSA next year, and so on...benefit helpline is useless. 4 carrier changes in 4 years, and you are on your own with comparing the benefit options and costs for each one. Comp plans penalize for high performance, and because the company is so large, it is next to impossible to address inequities and implement logical changes.

Title: "Really depends on your project and manager"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time
Pros: Supportive team members, nice place to work for people who wants stable life.
Cons: I've been on two teams at Dell and had experiences with two totally different types of managements. While working on the same product and giving good amount of effort for both teams, I got recognized well from the first manager, but was told that I was not working by my second manager while I worked till late nights every working day. When I have only worked for 9 months on the team, I was shown by the manager the amount of work of colleagues that has done over 2 years, and told that I was not doing the same amount of work! I was given minimum amount of training before put on project without choice, and was switched around to work on things that were not even within my field.

Title: "Pay Lacking"

Title: "Downhill"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: The pay ks competitive but its becoming less and less relevant
Cons:
As the Dell machine takes huge bites out of the EMC culture, bonuses have been cut from once a quarter to once a year and are being decreased by half. Pay raises are negligible  (2%) and now we can't carry over personal or vacation days. Perks for people that travel are being erased to the point of Architects are bailing at an alarming rate.
Health benefits are being cut as well this year. I assume if you're used to Mr Dells heavy handedness you're fine but anyone who are legacy EMC are being screwed.

Title: "Sr. Principal Solutions Engineer"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
Many different opportunities available. I was with them through the glory years, the downturn, the turn around, and the fade and merger. Through it all, I really enjoyed my time there. I always felt that it had a good engineering/technology focus. 

Always had plenty of different types of technology to work on and training/certification was encouraged.
Cons:
Suffered a bit from having too many products and the struggles of integrating products from acquired companies.

As hardware has become more and more marginalized, they are trying hard to shift to more software and services. They have done a good job but it's a constant struggle to compete with all the small players that pop up and steal mindshare and market share.

Title: "Sales success is becoming more difficult"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros:
Good benefits (401K, dental, medical, HSA, etc.)
Training is good.
Work-life balance is great if you have the guts to stick to it (most people fall for the carrot). 
Pay is between 36,000 and 60,000 (regardless of education or technical background). Just sell.
Cons:
Sales management is weak (high school diploma or college drop-outs). They have favorites when it comes to promotions and assigning territory (which determines how your career progresses or ends).
Sales quota is challenging.  
People with tenure haven't got a raise for years now (as of August 2017).
Unhealthy internal competition due to different incentive plans for team members.

Title: "Dell EMC"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Good benefits. Flexibility to work from home. Great team at the ground level. Great collaborators on the teams I interacted with cross-functionally. Basically, a great place to work at the individual level and one or two managerial levels above.  I worked for the Isilon Storage Division. The people I worked with are/were passionate and quality-focused. They built great relationships with other teams as well.
Cons: Isilon was acquired by EMC and then EMC merged with Dell. Prior to the Dell acquisition, our team was cited as an example for other teams to model and our content strategies were adopted by other teams. After the Dell merger it became clear that our contributions were no longer understood or valued. I was laid off by someone who maybe knew my name and salary. My direct manager wasn't consulted in advance. I can't recommend working for a company that makes decisions based on criteria that's unrelated to skills, contributions, value, and knowledge of the product. No job security here, regardless of the quality of your work.

Title: "review for small business segment"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year
Pros:
In the small business segment they definitely teach you as much as they can in training, so it's not a problem if you've never been in sales or don't know how computers work. Depending on the team your on (inbound or outbound) the KPI's are pretty reasonable.

Unlimited overtime, uncapped commission, lots of "competition" money available that's not considered part of your quoted pay or benefits, TONS of free food (like some weeks I never had to buy or bring lunch)

KPI's are predictable, and if you're not hitting those they have a good track record  for performance improvement plans. Lots of people go on PIPs and end up having great numbers in the months afterward.

Great opportunity to learn more about technology from both a hardware and software perspective AND once you're in the Dell network it's much easier to transfer to another department or position that you might find more attractive.
Cons:
Working in the small business segment is a little bit like working in a frat house. The reps are rowdy and whiny. While there are a number of more middle aged employees (people of all ages work on this floor), they tend to hire a lot of young people and recent grads which I think attributes to some of the rowdiness. There are so many "incentives" to sell that people end of coddled and throw a fit if they don't immediately get the gift card they won or the free lunch they were promised before. 

Things can change at the drop of a hat. I had an emergency and took a Friday off and when I came in Monday I had a new desk and a new manager. KPI's are predictable, but management will be really slack one week then bring the hammer down the next week (like firing people for not hitting very specific numbers). This pressures the reps to do some shady things. Sometimes management turns a blind eye to these things, especially if it's "technically" within the bounds of what's allowed. To give them credit, I have seen reps fired for doing unethical things, and one of the company's core values "Winning with Integrity" does come up a lot when people start mentioning those shady practices.

Work life balance is difficult. Putting in longer hours to learn more about the product and processes definitely helps in the beginning, and then even more so when longer hours mean more talk time with more customers. But obviously this is difficult if you have kids.

People get promoted based on good numbers and tenure. While I believe those both matter, a poor salesperson might actually make a good coach, and a good salesperson might make a terrible coach. I've heard of manager's not getting promoted to positions they deserved because they were 1 month outside the required tenure. That's a technicality and shouldn't matter if the person is skilled (which they were).

There's also this growing schism between what they practice and what they preach. Training was like this fairytale land where you could be good at your job and grow into the position with integrity. When you hit the floor it's like every man for himself and you do whatever you can to sell more. At times the manager's will encourage you do what you were trained on, and at other times they say the only things that matter are what you're.

Pros:

--Growth opportunities are endless. They encourage you to be open and honest about what type of positions you'd like to explore and your manager will (hopefully) help you in obtaining that next step
--WFH flexibility
--401k match
--Fast-paced with interesting projects always in the pipeline
Cons:
Sadly, most of the pros quickly dwindle if you get stuck with the wrong manager. I have had some of the best managers of my life here, and some of the worst that leave me stress ridden. "Mean girls" mentality basically sums it up. If you are unfortunate enough to have this happen to you, run, don't walk, to another job. It really is sad.

Work life balance is a pro and con...meaning yes, WFH flexibility, however, you'll more than likely be working so much it's difficult to find time to get away.

Title: "Large Micromanaged Company"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year
Pros: Dell has great benefits that begin from day one. They have product events regularly with free food, t-shirts, and giveaways.
Cons: This company is way too large to be micromanaged on the scale that it is. Presidents, Executive VPs, VPs, and Regional Sales Directors should not be so involved in the day-to-day of the lower level employees. Dell also makes it difficult for their customers to budget for their IT needs because they constantly change prices; sometimes week-to-week.

Title: "Was better than OK at first but everything started doing down hill years of change"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: I cant say much about the pros as I started hating the job due to many changes with the management and support teams being to district with the way it was being ran there own way. Perhaps the bonuses and gifts were probably the best things. In regards to gifts, they would give out like a $50 amazon gift card if you were performing well or something even better, or even time off from  the queue for as long as 2 hours and still get paid.
Cons:
Required approval from team leads or management on EVERY part that was to be sent out for replacement on each clients computers. Had to go by a stupid form  to trouble shoot a problem that you already know how to trouble shoot, they literally had to see the form results pasted in the notes on each call that we got.
Team leads that were hired 6 months from the role I started, running the show there way, example would be that if you didn't go by the form that you were supposed to follow, they will put you in a one on one with them in a room and had to explain why we're not following that form. If it continues, you had to sit with the team leads and the manager and threaten you with verbal warnings.
Also we had to open a case for every call that we take, and take ownership of that case until fully resolving there issue. There were more than many instances where we needed to get off the inbound calls, and take outbound time to make those calls to the customers we owned, but we're denied because of the queue being so slammed, and then we would get in trouble by the management as to why we haven't been touching our cases EVERY DAY! Little did they realize they never gave us the time to do so, it was like slaving in there. 
Another thing is that they are always hiring, you would see a group of 20+ people every 2-3 months take a training class, after almost 2 month of training and start taking calls on the floor. Possibly about 65-80% of those people that was hired had left Dell within a time frame of 1-3 months after there training as it was just to complicated for them with the way this business is running.

Title: "Going downhill fast!!!!"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: The benefits we had an EMC were amazing. The medical/dental plans that were offered were spectacular compared to what else is out there. The vacation time was also comparable too.
Cons: When we were acquired by Dell everything went downhill. There was no communication from the Dell side. We were not included in any decisions or communication. Everything we got was filtered through other people. We were trying to integrate the two systems (I worked in HR) and they would send out the wrong link to employees and we on the EMC HR side would have to deal with all of the question. They would never send out a follow up email stating the correct link. And we were not allowed to send anything out to clarify.

Title: "Change or Die!"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time
Pros: large company, huge footprint now, tons of customers and partners, innovative technology
Cons: So far Change = Take something away every month. Every kind of perk or benefit or feature that isn't bolted down is being eliminated. Dell also loved them some H1b's (despite there being plenty of talent and skillset here stateside) so to adapt to the current administration in Washington there is a huge push to move everything and anything to COE (India) so it's definitely not a pro-american worker environment. Finally there are now what seems like thousands of VP's and each one is in charge of what seems like one thing. We get emails from every single one of them every single day for their particular responsibility (ex. laptops, training, expenses, benefits, sales, marketing, mobile, etc).

Title: "It's all about the bottom dollar."
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
There are some pretty awesome people working for this company. 
Decent benefits and decent pay.
It's really hard to come up with many pros, sadly.
Cons:
To keep it simple, here is the list of struggles at the company: 
1. Lack of female leadership throughout the entire company.
2. Horrible work-life balance
3. My manager has had multiple complaints about her from vendors and other co-workers within the company, yet HR chalks it up to a communication issue. She is a bully. 
4. I wanted to like Dell, but post merger they continued to make changes that made it feel like they cared more about profit than the employees.
5. Having worked for several large companies, this is by far the worst employment experience I've ever had.

Title: "Company in transition"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time
Pros: Good pay, benefits, work environment

Title: "Meritocracy for some"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: Great benefits, work from home/flexible schedule, competitive pay
Cons: Dell prides itself on being a meritocracy; promoting based on merit, but they can't always live up to it. My experience was I worked  in a small group of 70 employees and that group was only allowed to promote one individual in a given year due to the internal politics of promotions/budgets. I was on the promotion track and leading up to my end of year review was told I was doing everything required to be promoted to the next pay level. Then when the year ended I was not promoted and was told it was because there are so many talented people in my group the promotion had to go to XYZ person. I did work in an amazing group with top-knotch people, but when the company limits how many promotions they can assign due to budgets based on group size that isn't in line with their meritocracy philosophy.

Title: "Deleted all evidence of work"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Michael Dell called my desktop twice during my tenure at Dell. The first time was to make sure I would be viable after I volunteered to take a furlough. Mr. Dell also assured me he would pay me back. The second time, he called to yell at me for a customer escalation. I did fix it.
Cons:
Before coming to Dell and during my tenure I had established with linux kernel developers via the linux kernel mailing list. I was able to use my relationship between Dell Engineering and the opensource team to make introduction and solve problems for Dell. I gained a lot of visibility with both teams. 

Under duress a Dell leverage my relationship with the linux team and donated servers for the mailing linux. The trade off was, linux kernel team deleted all traces of my contribution to the linux kernel from the archive. The reasoning was because they, in my opinion, was they felt threaten because at the time I was a low level employee, and could leverage the major players for the linux kernel. This went all the up to a VP level.

Dell culture is one that they will hire anyone regardless of education. However, a lot of people feel very insecure about the jobs.

Before, I left the company, various account teams leveraged me a lot to resolve the customer escalation. I worked a very high level, and all my customer escalation were resolved.  I was there "goto guy".

The reason for the review is since, After, I left the company for a number of years on the Dell EMC companies recruited me for a performance engineer job. It would have been great to show my linux contribution history.

Title: "Too much management, not enough talent."
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year
Pros: Profitable company that distinctly has a financial future.
Cons:
There seems to be no real distinct Dell culture, outside of the traces of culture that float around from other companies it has acquired.  For the most part the company is embodiment of the old IBM stereo-typical "shirt and tie" business model that died with the boom of tech startups.

Dell seems to be demonstrating a desire to prove that it can manage the merger of companies that it acquires regardless of how much mind-share/talent/culture it looses during the acquisition.  At one point in time we had 1 Manager and 2 Project Managers overseeing the work of 6 IT administrators.  All the while we were being told that our future would be pivoting the focus to process/procedure over productivity/performance.

Title: "Focused but short sighted"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: EMC provides good work-life balance.
Cons:
EMC used to be a great company that can strike good balance between current product, and visionary investments/research in 3-5 years. EMC employees used to believe they work on cutting edge greatest storage solutions. 
The acquisition by DELL changed all that. 1 year after the acquisition, DELL has cut all programs that aren't profiting now, and are looking very closely at ROI of each running program. This changes behavior of people. Now all leaders care about is sale, market, but not building great product anymore.

Compensation and Perks used to be good at EMC but are being cut down by DELL.

Title: "Dell/EMC"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
Work/life balance was excellent. Benefits were great under EMC. Still decent under Dell, but changing.

Co-workers and most other employees were very talented, great to partner with.
Cons:
What's left of the culture is layoffs. It's all about restructure and changing everything that was once EMC. 

Management doesn't really have a clue. Never did, but it became worse once the "merger" was completed. 

Absolutely no opportunity for advancement if you don't know people or do not have friends or relatives in senior leadership positions. 

Excellent performers aren't rewarded fairly, but this is a product of the organization you work for and your leadership team. If you bring up the fact that you aren't being rewarded, certain managers essentially ignore the feedback and try to fluff other areas to make it look like they care.

Title: "Thankless job with no upside"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies  for more than 8 years
Pros: Ability to work remotely which provides schedule flexibility.  Building an internal network is key to success at Dell. If you have good managers this process is easy, if not, well it can be the difference between success and failure.
Cons: Compensation is mediocre and benefits are lacking. Do more with less is the mantra so hours are very long and don't expect anyone to ever say Thank You.. Career paths are not clear and if you ever want a promotion prepare to wait many many years and put up with an abundance of political BS.

Title: "Worst edtech corporate job I have ever had"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year
Pros: I did make a few colleagues that had the same passion as I did in the k12 learning space, and they too have since departed Dell from a sales and edtech team  stand point.
Cons: The environment is extremely toxic across most teams. It is a  truly a good ole boy culture/network. Little to no advancement for women, and women are devalued due to their "leaning in" of sharing their intelligent knowledge and ideas. Women's ideas are taken and education male team members reclaim them as their own. Leadership on the global and national perspective from the k12 educational team is male driven with little to no classroom or k12 leadership experiences. The male dominant team have been out of the classroom role for more than 15+ years, making their leadership styles, views and k12 education voice stale and irrelevant. The women members of the k12 education are the worker bees and are viewed as the mandatory doers of the delegated task lists. If you want to kill your creativity and have your professional character and image devalued quickly as an educator, then you would be the right fit on this disjointed k12 education team. They need to do some major housecleaning/ vetting of the male leaders and  directors to make change and to be truly respected in the k12 teaching and learning space.

Title: "The good and not so good side of Dell."
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for less than a year
Pros: Large company that offers generous personal and vacation time with decent benefits from healthcare to movie discounts.
Cons: Very strict company policies that contradict each other which can cause unnecessary stress to employees that I personally have seen to cause mental health issues and even cases of depression and suicidal thoughts.

Title: "Cog in a wheel"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
Dell name looks good on your resume
Michael Dell has decided to move to the Data Center market, lap tops are still a core business.
Moves at glacier pace/slow due to being a global company- must follow the process no matter how inane it might be
If you can last here at an "IT" company longer than 6 years...you have learned the "Dell way--nuances"
They like to hire from within Dell because the internal hires have learned these nuances... you don't say it, you just KNOW what they are insinuating. Interesting place.
HR and Talent Acquisition are "trying" to allow employees to work remote, but most business groups won't allow this. You can be wandering the campus, but they want you see you around.
Cons:
Politics- ugh! 
Salaries low for IT company
Is A private company, so unlike most IT companies, they do not offer-- stock options as part of a package just a 8, 10 or 15% annual bonus to your salary. To compensate for lack of stock, they offer the engineers an additional bonus called LTI.
Managers are so concerned about hurting people's feelings that communication isn't really "real"- you get the double talk.
Felt like a had a new direct manager every 3-6 months. There for 2+ years.

Title: "Depends On Segment and Manager"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
Vacation: 3 weeks a year + 1 week at Christmas 
Benefits: Insurance is okay 
Sick time: 2 weeks 
Possible work from home depending on situation and manager

Potential for large commission checks if provided with good spend account and attainable quota.
Cons:
inconsistent quotas 
very micromanaged 
heavily measured on "check the box" tasks 

depending on your manager you may have a good experience, but as a working mother I was constantly having to choose between my son and my job. My husband had more flexibility and was able to attend more school activities and doctors appointments. 

HR is always in benefit to the company and retaliation is real. Eventually it gets so toxic you just have to quit. 

If my kid was sick on a non work from home day I couldn't be flexible and switch out my days. 

200 question product knowledge test in order to promote 

many hoops to jump through to promote it's all about networking not about the results.

Title: "Project Manager"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies  for more than 8 years
Pros: the people, especially the new hires, who are willing to do anything in order to make a difference.  It is sad to see the light leave their eyes when, after time, they realize the company doesn't care if they grow in their job or not.
Cons:
Dell has no employee development program, so unless you bring something to the table you are not going to get hired (i.e. no recruiting of undergraduates on college campuses). The company hires the talent it needs , work them to death, and then lays them off when they are no longer useful.  This same cycle has played itself out several times in the past 25 years.

This who just look at Dell for a job (as opposed to a career) can make it through the cycles because they are not usually the high dollar earners.

Title: "Consultant"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Work/life balance is pretty fair depending on the department.  The cafeteria food has a healthy variety, and the fitness facilities are good for the monthly investment.
Cons: Dell fosters a toxic culture in which screaming at subordinates is considered strong.  If you're with the "in" crowd, then almost nothing you do in the name of "driving for results" could be bad.  It's a mercenary environment to say the least.  Personal insults made via faceless phone calls and email terrorism maintain the politics of fear.  The core message is:  there is a long line of people that are more educated and willing to work for half your salary; keep looking over your shoulder.  You could be the victim of the regular, quarterly Workforce Reduction at any moment.

Title: "Cheap company"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: There are a lot of mediocre people there so if you are a star, you will shine brightly and get rewarded.
Cons: The rewards you get will not be money.  Dell is a very cheap company.  They do not invest in their employees or morale.  It's a turn em and burn em company.  If you want to get industry experience and learn a lot, both what to do and what not to do, this is a good place to do a tour of duty.  If you don't have time for that, then avoid it.  The level of politics and internal competition between teams is insane.  But if you decide you don't care, you can phone it in and collect a paycheck for a few years before anyone notices.

Title: "It is a mixed bag"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time
Pros:
1: Great Benefits
2: New and innovative technologies
3: Most of the people on the peer level are great people and good to work with
4: Good work life balance.  Work does not ever, or rarely, follows you home!
5: Privately owned now with a demonstrated leader!
6: Emphasis on giving back to the community and world
Cons:
1: Org changes that never complete before a new one is kicked off
2: Poorly managed and executed initiatives that never complete or are run by people lacking the necessary experience for the initiative.  Such as a change to Agile orchestrated by someone who has never done Agile.
3: Politics, infighting, possessiveness, and general hostility between managers.
4: No clear direction.
5: Poor recognition of accomplishments and contributions.
6: If you come in as entry level the compensation will be below market value and so will the growth opportunities.

Title: "A siloed and clunky management system of governance"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Great Benefits, and an amazing severance plan!
Cons:
Management was often forced to read the corporate management slides quarterly.   They'd read the text, and click next for each slide.  When this first happened I thought it was a joke.  There was no emotion, and silent giggles as they tripped over the words.  

Management was driven by a 'What you were not doing" approach to motivation rather than "What are you doing right?" approach. Very negative culture.  This eventually sucked the life out of me, and I ended up following a "Cover your arse" approach to work. I lost my adventurism and risk taking approach within two years of being there.  They would do reviews based on what your junior peers were saying about you, and not what you actually did.

Title: "Sales Specialist - data storage, servers and networking"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: compensation if you are there long enough is very good. Better online training now that EMC is in the mix. Good products which customers like.
Cons: In sales they move you into new positions without consulting you.  This happened in 2016 like every 90 days or so.For example, they would often change selling roles from a pure sales specialist to a technical consultant even though you may not be a very technical type like a systems engineer. You have no choice in this movement, you either accept the new role or leave.  Quotas are huge and basically unattainable. They change your account list at the drop of a hat. So the hard work you put into an account can be yanked away in 90 days. Dell says that they want their sales force to be considered  "trusted advisors" by their customers, but not really.  70% of sales people are on a performance plan at Dell at any point of time. Dell acquired EMC in 2016 and has taken over the sales process. The inside and outside sales people at Dell are top notch and pounded for numbers. Lastly, delivery on components can be a big problem. Dell had multiple months of notice on this coming component shortage problem and didn't plan well. The sales people suffered the pain and lost many sales due to this since Dell couldn't ship the necessary parts.

Pros: Some of the best people I have ever worked with. We were always encouraged to think outside the box. The senior leadership team led by example. It was the largest company I ever worked for and yet felt like the smallest - it was a true team environment. Great work-life balance.
Cons: Middle management often got in the way. The Executive Director level people I worked for are the reason I left the company. Everyone else - senior executives, vice presidents, directors and below - was fabulous. Not a lot of opportunity for career advancement.

Title: "Dell - Good People / Great Atmosphere"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Great People,  Good Products to sell, market, create and support.   For the most part people are very proud to be Dell Employees and I think this is very strong especially in Round Rock, TX location.
Cons: Sometimes job postings and interview process can be very delayed - be patient.

Title: "Collapse of VCE"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Good benefits to include PTO
Cons: Individual thinking seems not to be encouraged anymore.

Title: "Principal Developer"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time
Pros: As EMC, it had a complete employee experience. Since Dell has acquired it, things are not on right path. Too much politics on the floor, hasty decisions from the people who company themselves don't rely on. Laying off people based on the people they lay off too for their performance.
Cons: After the EMC merger with Dell, employees have lost the enthusiasm to work for a firm. People are constantly at their toes to make a move and as a immigrant, I personally had bitter experience, where they will lay you off, without even giving a single thought about how will you manage to leave the country in given 15 days.  Never work for this company - It may have bigger name, but floor talks are different than what you see on social media.

Title: "Innovation powerhouse"

3. Great people, fantastic colleagues. Technically and non-technically a very happy place to work .
4. Work-Life balance: The Leadership resources projects well, hence much of the pressure for releases is mitigated. 
5. Diversity, Inclusion and hires a lot of people from Local universities. 
6. Aggressive Sales, Marketing and Product management teams
7. CEO is Micheal Dell :-)
Cons:
1. Long term vision is sometimes lost in the noise of short term goals.
2. Some teams have way more visibility and access compared to other teams. This leads to skewed messaging and folks sometimes feel left out.

Title: "Challenging culture"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros:
-Great pay
-All the training you could want
-First class sales organization
Cons: The biggest con is the culture of the company.  When EMC first started they had a near monopoly on the data center storage market.  As a result, an arrogance started to develop where customers were told to take it or leave it.  Eventually, competitors came about but a lot of that arrogance still remains.  I think that EMC will see more long term success when they temper their attitude.  It does not sit well with customers and leaves a bad taste in their mouths.

Title: "Dell - the good and the bad"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 10 years

Title: "Pro-Support Sr. Associate"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for less than a year
Pros:
Brand recognition, able to enter the tech field without much experience due to training.

Great environment to gain knowledge and insight about computers. Continued learning with certificate earning. 

Great benefits.
Cons:
Dell has very low retention rates because they micro-manage and under appreciate their employees. The micro-managing is from top level down exploiting the employee and over demanding. They do not pay for everything that you're doing and the L2's 9/10 times are not helpful and get upset when you ask for help constantly as you're trying to learn. 

Metrics are messed up. If you're out of town for vacation, your metrics keep running and lower your numbers which affect you, Your CE is a apart of your metrics which does not help. For example, if a customer is upset because you can't send out a hard drive because of policy rules, the customer can then review you and give you a 1 on your rating from 1 to 10 and bring your CE down massively just because you were following the rules.

Management rarely backs you up and management is terrible. There are some pretty terrible managers out there some who do not have the proper training to lead. 

Your metrics can go down by simply doing your job. If a customer hangs up the phone, you have to call them back and you get bad metrics for returning a call. How is it your fault that the customer disconnected the phone? 

If the customer calls back in for whatever reason even though you're continuously emailing him/her, you get metrics hit.

The metrics prevent you from succeeding there to your full potential. Not much career advancement. 

Extra hard work and effort is not recognized so half the time you're making the same as the guy who is just sliding by at work. 

People quit 3-4 months in the job so you're always having to help train the newbees. 

No work life balance at all. If you're going in at work at 9:00AM and suppose to get off at 6PM, you might not get off until 8:00PM. You can literally receive a call 30 seconds before you're suppose to get off and you can't transfer the call so you really can't make commitments because you never know when you're going to get off. 

You can get in trouble for needing to use the restroom because of ACD. A lot of employees develop anxiety and have high stress levels because of this job and people are truly underappreciated. 

Senior Management always states that "this is the most difficult job in the company" and understand that they are underpaying their employees.

Title: "Dell strategy good, tactically in chaos"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: Dell is a great place to work, the people are great, the culture is very consensus oriented, and they believe in the community.  Job opportunities are abundant where investment is deemed necessary, though much of this seems very short-term given the amazing growth and changes Del is going through.
Cons: Strategy seems sound, but tactically many organizations are in chaos.  There is no strategic top to bottom.  More top is strategy, bottom is pure tactics.  Like many corporations there is very filtered discussion around strategy.  Sharing challenges, cons or other areas of problems is not shared well.  The culture focuses on the pros.  The open door policy is good when the news is good, otherwise best to keep to yourself.  2 things truly bother me here.  Firstly, there is little strategic planning across BUs (including cross-selling GTM activities), and little if any from the Executive Director level down.  Much of what occurs below VPs appears to be very reactive.  This affects people greatly, often having to "work around" process issues, system issues and departmental dysfunction.

Title: "Great company to work for, but..."
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: In terms of benefits and culture, Dell was one of the best companies I ever worked for. Their policies are very family-friendly, and they provided a generous package of vacation, days off for other needs, 401K, healthcare, etc. I was dubious about the prospects of working for Dell when they acquired my company, but it turned out to be a mostly positive experience. I'm sorry my 3 years there ended.
Cons: Like any large company, Dell has internal bureaucracies that are inefficient and often maddening. The timecard system is decades old, slow, and unstable; the security policies, such as changing passwords every 60 days, are nonsensical; etc. But my biggest complaint stems from their decision to enter the software business, acquiring companies left and right, and then deciding to abandon software, laying off hundreds of people and divesting the remaining pieces. Hardware companies have the wrong DNA to do software, and Michael Dell should have known this. The acquisitions followed by layoffs damaged careers and destroyed good products. Dell did a disservice to many people through this "experiment".

Title: "Sales Support / Sales Operations"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: As with all companies, it comes down to your leader.  I was fortunate to have a leader that was very experienced at navigating the Dell machine and made sure that I achieved the milestones necessary to move along my career path over the few years I reported into him.  Raises and bonuses were great (again, it comes down to your leader).  I'm now in management.  The 401K matching is great, the medical benefits were ok...  a bit on the expensive side when compared to my spouses that works at a similar sized company.
Cons: 1. Dell is a machine and unless you know have to navigate through this machine, it can take forever to get something done.  2. Spans and layers; at least 8 direct reports to be a manager  3. Non-industry standard career level titles; Sr. Consultant or Sr. Advisor are sound as if you aren't an actual employee but in fact are higher level individual contributor roles   3. Because there's opportunity to transfer to other roles internally, there aren't very many SME's (subject matter experts); it takes a room full of people to get anything done - I come from a smaller acquisition company where having a full understand of a process or program was not uncommon.  4. Dell doesn't provide "free coffee"...  the provide the Flavia Machine but the employees have to bring their own k-cups LOL

Title: "Little chance for growth with little to no culture..."
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year
Pros:
+Work/life balance can be good...
+Most of the folks are nice, but...
+Nice amenities like a built in cafeteria and in house nurse.
Cons:
-Most folks are nice, but they rarely want to make conversation. Not saying we need to be friends, but the team I was on felt lifeless at times as everyone just wanted to work and go home.
-The offices and rooms lack imagination and have "dull" lighting that dampens the mood.
-Work/life balance can become terrible at times. Working 10-12 hours a day for long stretches. A lot of it due to not enough resources on the team.
-Health insurance is awful. One of the worst I've seen and pathetic for a big as company as this.
-Two weeks vacation is "average" for an American company, but falls behind the more progressive Tech companies.
-Very little growth for the company results in very little growth promotion and pay wise.
-Pay is pathetic compared to other competitors. I'm currently making 13k more at my current gig with a "lesser" title.

Title: "Good job; bad management"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than a year
Pros: Assigned accounts; access to training; customers are thankful when you do well; perks include prizes, food, vendor gifts, offsite activities
Cons: Be prepared to be micromanaged like you've never experienced before. If you do well, you'll be expected to do better. If you don't, you'll be expected to account for every activity you perform all day. There is a Starbucks in the building; however, if your numbers are down (no matter what the reason), don't bother because you'll be harassed relentlessly by managers. Hard work is not recognized. Management is inexperienced and treat workers like children and create cliques like high school.

Title: "Dell Lincoln"

Pros: It is an ok place to work.

Title: "Solid workplace, good employees often poached."
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
Culturally, the place feels positive and solid in the teams I have worked under. I haven't encountered toxic workplaces here. The company seems fairly pro-employee, and you'll encounter employees that have had long runs of employment with the company.

Vacation time policy, sick time, 401k-match all feel like good benefits, and the company puts in effort to cultivate employees if the company direction has to change or the employee is struggling.
Cons:
Raises within a position are very small or nonexistent here - if you want to increase your pay after entering a position, you'll need to either change positions or leave the company if internal advancement is not possible.

When changing positions, there's a 'cap' on the possible increase in salary - because this exists, an externally-hired employee could be offered more than a better-qualified internally-hired employee for a given position. This combined with stagnant raises can undermine the statement of 'meritocracy' they drive internally.

Overall company direction has been very acquisition-heavy, but they haven't made the most of the acquisitions they've paid for. This feels like it may be sourced from a lack of agility that can often come with being a large company, but that's an externally-positioned viewpoint.

Title: "Dell is not American any more"
WorkTime: I worked at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
Dell provides flexible work hours
Dell provides good benefits
Cons:
Dell relies heavily on outsourcing jobs in USA to other countries like India. Both tech and management jobs in USA are outsourced to India. They lay-off US employees and hire H1 visa employees.
If you are an employee working in US you will have to get adjusted to a remote Indian manager dictating your career at Dell
There is always lots of 'us' and 'them' in any team at Dell and does not use any collaboration mechanisms to function as Global team
Agile practices are namesake and not updated with the latest technology stack. Still uses huge monolithic Applications and mainframe.
Most of the Managers in India are not qualified for the job and loyalty plays the key role than performance to get promoted. This is a red flag for many aspiring US tech job seekers at Dell.
Dell has scaled up its assets to the likes of Amazon, Microsoft, Google with the merger of EMC but not focused like their competitors in terms of driving company to position in future technology marketplace. 
Dell has mediocre pay

Title: "Global marketing"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 5 years
Pros:
Passionate and smart co-workers, fast-paced, focus really is on delivering the best experience for customers. Very complex operations with few centralized or documented processes - but teams work with openness and transparency.  Dell employee culture (at headquarters) is unique, the only place I've ever worked where co-workers openly share information and are happy to  answer any questions or work to help find an answer if they don't know.   Employees are empowered to make decisions and propose solutions from the bottom up.

Work from home focus brings freedom and allows people to do their best work in the setting most suited to them while keeping balance between home and life.
Cons: Complex operations with few centralized or documented processes can get in the way of delivery. (Even though that also leads to opportunities.)  Changes to culture with merger are bringing top-down marching orders and secrecy where openness and empowerment once lived.

Cons:
The Dell takeover (don't call it a merger) is settling in. Thousands being let go as the new entity rationalizes product portfolios. In particular, managers are at risk as Dell mandates specific span of control ratios. EMC favored a player-coach model so many managers need to go. 

Dell views management as overhead and overhead is the enemy in a low margin business.

Title: "Sales"
WorkTime: I have been working at Dell Technologies full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Great people, good sales managers, great benefits (lots of vacation including an extra week for Christmas, great training
Cons:
Upper management does not care about employees (C-level executive said "if I missed my number more than twice I would want to put a gun to my head" to a room full of salespeople at a conference), internal processes are so bad it's mind-boggling, major "success tax" when it comes to hitting or over-attaining on number, quotas are unrealistic, constant war of messaging between marketing (customer-first) and sales (sell, sell, sell). 

You get stuck with a patch of 90-100 set accounts and you can never acquire new customers unless they get rotated to you by management. Eventually you will get stuck in a bad patch and be in danger of a PIP (Performance Improvement Plan) regardless of how good at sales you are. Very high turnover because of this.

Used to be great but lately it's been a nightmare working there.
